author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: Ravi Shankar Prasad to officials: Avoid encryption draft-like fiascos
text:
NEW DELHI: Union communications and IT minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has asked senior officials to put in processes to ensure fiascos such as the one created by the draft National Encryption Policy early this week don't happen again.

Taking a grim view of this week's events, when the draft policy was withdrawn following a public outcry, Prasad has called for better coordination and communication among different arms of the ministry, government sources said.

A new set of advisory will be issued to all concerned in the departments of electronics and IT (DeitY) and telecom to step out of their silos and ensure sufficient channels of communication between levels, they said. Measures would include ensuring more diligence on matters relating to sensitive issues like national security and privacy, which attract immediate public reactions, especially given the deepening influence of social media. Also, all sensitive matters would need to be vetted at higher levels before being released in public domain, sources said.

DeitY was forced to withdraw the controversial 'draft encryption policy' just over 12 hours after making it public late on Monday after it came under severe criticism, especially on social media, for its move to make individuals legally bound to retain personal chats/messages and provide to law authorities, if asked.

Insiders said timing of the policy release -- just before Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to the US where he would meet Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg among others -- had left the ministry red faced and forced the document's withdrawal. "The problem that happened (withdrawal of the draft policy) was not because of any intent on part of an officer but due to miscommunication or lack of communication and we will try and clearly establish certain procedures," a senior government official told ET. "We are now trying to encourage much more communication and consultation to avoid fiascos."

Besides the encryption policy episode other policy flip-flops that hurt the ministry in recent times include a ban on 800 porn websites and its subsequent roll back, again after a social media backlash.

The new advisory may also seek to increase the role of public participation in policy formation by inviting comments on matters that affect consumers of technology. "We would like to incorporate views and aspirations of people at large through public consultations such as the one on 'encryption' to make the final policies more relevant and user friendly," the official said. Officials said the language and methodology of consulting the public will be made much more 'reader friendly' and 'engaging'.

All officials ET spoke to said the speed of technology usage and adoption required the government to restructure and refashion its processes and systems in much lesser time. "In this particular case, the word 'users' (in the draft encryption policy) was misinterpreted. We will need to be much clearer and sharper in our communication. It is an evolving process and we will soon be there," said the official quoted earlier.
